V29.0951; V95.0951.001    Pearce    Mon/Wed    11-12:15    Spanish; Taught in English    Course Descriptions     Diaries of Modernity: The Chronicle and Cultural History in Latin America Dopico Thurs 2:00- 4:45pm V29.0550.001; V95.0990.005  This course will consider the importance of the Latin American crónica and its engagements with modernity in the nineteenth and twentieth century. It will examine how nineteenth century practitioners worked the genre didactically and aesthetically to establish a common Latin American imaginary, to educate a burgeoning reading public in worldly tastes and cosmopolitanisms, to take up hemispheric political problems, and to focus on the problems of uneven modernity and the comparative anxieties of Latin Americans looking to Europe and the United Status as models of progress, development and democracy. We will also consider how the chronicle as a journalistic form emphazies a documentary imperative and competes with photography as primary material and cultural currency. In the second half of the course, we will explore the twentieth century journalism of “master novelists” whose previous incarnations as journalists shaped their work and consider their literary experiments beyond their conventional interpretations. We will think about the force of photography and visual culture in non-fiction writing, and consider how movements like modernism, surrealism, new journalism and the marvelous real participate in a mutualistic relationship with the cronica as a journalistic and literary form. Finally we will read recent works whose authors exploit the cronicas liminal generic status to invent a new narrative transit between literature, journalism, and historiography while competing with and assimilating the aesthetics and representational force of photography and cinema. A photographic anthology will often accompany the weekly readings.                   Back to Top                     Contact us | © New York University , Arts and Science

                         Back to  previous page              &nbsp;       &nbsp;     Spring 2014 | Cross Listed Undergraduate Courses Originating in Other Departments       Courses Originating in the Comparative Literature Department             Course Name    Credits    Course Number    Professor    Day    Time    Originates in       Barthes’ Attachments (Taught in English.)    4.0    COLIT-UA 865 FREN-UA 865.001 Apter    Thursday    2:00-4:45 French  Dante and His World    4.0    COLIT-UA 173 ITAL-UA 160 Ardizzone    Mon/Wed    12:30-1:45 Italian       Introduction to Theory: Critical Theory from Plato to Adorno and Beyond    4.0    COLIT-UA 249 GERM-UA 249 Itkin    Mon/Wed 3:30-4:45 German  Al-Andalus and Modern Fiction    4.0    COLIT-UA 951.001 SPAN-UA 951 Pearce    Tues/Thurs    11:00-12:15 Spanish  On Eating Others: Cannibalism and Anthropophagy in the Circum-Atlantic World    4.0    COLIT-UA 951.002 SPAN-UA 851 Robbins    Mon/Wed    11:00-12:15 Spanish  Historical Epics of China and Japan    4.0    COLIT-UA 726 EAST-UA 726 Roberts    Monday    11:00-1:45 East Asian  The German Intellectual Tradition: The Myth of the Machine: From Divine Automata to the Internet    4.0    COLIT-UA 244 GERM-UA 244    Weatherby    Tues/Thurs    11:00-12:15 German  20th Century Korean Literature in Translation    4.0    COLIT-UA 611 EAST-UA 611 Yi    Mon/Wed    2:00-3:15 East Asian         Barthes’ Attachments Apter     Introduction to Theory: Critical Theory from Plato to Adorno and Beyond  Itkin     The German Intellectual Tradition: The Myth of the Machine: From Divine Automata to the Internet Weatherby We live in a world of technological mediation. Devices provide us with the rules--for geographical orientation, for dating, for knowing the weather. Do we use our devices, or do they use us? The question is old, and this course looks at cultures of machines from the Early Modern period to the present. It will proceed thematically, treating problems in historical technological cultures like computers (Pascal, Babbage, Kittler), automata (Vaucanson, Hoffmann, Helmholtz, Merimee, Čapek), divine machines (Leibniz, Jean Paul, Wiener, Günther), the advent of film (Münsterberg, Lang, Benjamin), animals/humans and "the tool" (Geroi-Lourhan, Heidegger, Darwin/Marx, Engels, Kapp, Samuel Butler) and the so-called "megamachine" of modern society (Jünger, Mumford). The framework will be the negative anthropology tradition between Herder and Gehlen and the reversal of the myth from the extension of human powers to the primacy of the technological. The shared conviction of nearly all these authors is that culture must reflect on its machines--and on itself as a machine-like entity--in order to survive.
